Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)

Promoting Evidence-Based Policy Making for Gender 
Equity in the Pacific 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status   
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) recognizes gender equity as an essential driver of 
change in achieving inclusive development, and emphasizes gender mainstreaming in all ADB 
operations.1 For the  Pacific  developing member  countries  (DMCs),  ADB  aims  to  introduce 
gender as a key policy concern in the core functioning of governments by enhancing gender 
awareness in all capacity- and institution-building efforts.2 A 2008 regional technical assistance 
(TA)  project  assessed  gender  mainstreaming  capacity  in  governments  of  selected  Pacific 
DMCs.3 The  results  indicate  a  great  need  to  improve  gender  awareness  across  Pacific 
governments and to develop institutional and technical capacities of government agencies to 
promote gender equity.    
 
2.  The TA for Promoting Evidence-Based Policy Making for Gender Equity in the Pacific 
seeks to strengthen the capacity of governments in selected Pacific DMCs to systematically 
monitor gender situations and address gender inclusiveness in development strategies. Fact-
finding missions were undertaken during June–September 2010 to the Fiji Islands, Papua New 
Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Timor-Leste. All the governments requested support for capacity 
development,  especially  for  staff  of  women’s  offices  and  sector  gender  focal  points,  in 
monitoring  gender  inequalities  and  promoting  gender  mainstreaming  across  government 
ministries.  The  objective,  scope,  implementation  arrangements,  cost  and  financing 
arrangements, and terms of references for the TA are based on the understanding reached with 
the governments during the missions.4 The design and monitoring framework for the TA is 
presented in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Pacific DMCs share common concerns and challenges in achieving social and 
economic development goals, including gender equity. Many Pacific countries rank very low in 
the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  human  development  and  gender-related 
development indexes, with poor performance on the basic health and education indicators, 
particularly among women. In countries such as Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and 
Timor-Leste, the gender gap in school enrollment persists together with low enrollment rates. 
Maternal  mortality  rates for  these  countries  are  among the  highest  in  the  world  with  little 
indication of improvement, reflecting the lack of women’s empowerment at various levels. In 
addition, low participation of women in the economy and decision-making positions, along with 
widespread gender-based violence, are critical concerns for improving women’s status.   
 
4.  Across  the  Pacific  DMCs,  gender  awareness  has  been  gradually  increasing  with 
ratification of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women 
(CEDAW)5 and  with  growing  emphasis  on  gender  equality  by  international  and  regional 
agencies. Yet, there have been few systematic and concerted policy efforts to address gender 
concerns in national development strategies across the Pacific DMCs. This lack of systematic 
effort reflects weak government capacity overall and poor technical capacity of government

agencies that represent women’s interests in the national policy agenda. In particular, women’s 
ministries and sector gender focal points often lack technical capacity to assess and monitor 
gender disparities in key social and economic areas, which is essential for articulating gender 
concerns and developing targeted policies. Moreover, limited availability of empirical data in the 
Pacific and limited capability to use existing information hinder the capacity of policy makers to 
make informed decisions on gender issues.   
 
5.  Recently, progress has been made in collecting administrative and statistical data in 
many Pacific DMCs, including sex-disaggregated statistics. Despite increasing availability of 
empirical  data,  the  data  have  not  been  effectively  utilized  in  measuring,  monitoring,  and 
assessing gender disparities, let alone in  assisting informed policy making on gender and 
development  issues.  Collecting  and  analyzing  gender  indicators  is  crucial  for  developing 
targeted measures to reduce gender disparities, as well as for monitoring the outcomes of 
implemented policies or programs. Regular collection and dissemination of gender indicators 
can  also  facilitate  working  relationships  across  government  agencies,  increase  gender 
awareness among policy makers, and promote gender mainstreaming in government programs 
and donor-assisted development projects. In addition, regular monitoring of gender disparities 
based  on  empirical  data  provides  an  important  tool  to  evaluate  resource  allocations  in 
government planning, programming, and budgeting.     
 
6.  To facilitate integration of gender concerns in the national development strategies of 
Pacific DMCs, it is important to increase gender awareness and support capacity building both 
in governments and civil society. This can be achieved by promoting evidence-based policy 
making on gender issues. Improving the technical capacity of women’s ministries and gender 
focal points to utilize empirical information, monitor gender situations, and disseminate the 
findings across government ministries and civil society are essential elements of evidence-
based  policy  making.  This  process  in  turn  will  create  an  enabling  institutional  and  policy 
environment that advances gender mainstreaming and gender equity.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be the attainment of gender-inclusive development in selected 
Pacific DMCs. The expected outcome of the TA is improved capacity of women’s ministries and 
sector gender focal points to promote evidence-based, gender-inclusive policy development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The  TA  will  support  capacity  development  of  key  government  agencies,  especially 
women’s offices and sector gender focal points, for evidence-based policy making on gender 
issues.  The  TA  outputs  will  be  delivered  through  (i)  the  compilation  of  baseline  gender 
indicators, (ii) country gender assessments (CGAs), (iii) gender awareness training and gender-
inclusive policy development, and (iv) regional knowledge sharing on gender disparities in 
Pacific DMCs.   
 
9.  The countries participating in the TA are the Fiji Islands, Papua New Guinea, Solomon 
Islands, and Timor-Leste. These are the largest countries in the Pacific, and they face various 
gender-related  constraints  in  alleviating  poverty,  fostering  economic  growth,  and  ensuring 
inclusive development. In Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Timor-Leste, women’s 
poor human resources, lack of access to economic opportunities, and pervasive gender-based

3 
violence  have  been  highlighted  as  serious  barriers  to  the  country’s  development.  These 
countries have also lacked reliable empirical information for many years, making systematic 
assessments of gender disparities or promotion of evidence-based policy making on gender 
concerns difficult. In the Fiji Islands, deteriorating economic opportunities for women have been 
a growing developmental concern; yet, a comprehensive gender analysis has been lacking to 
assess the situation. The TA is timely for these countries, given that they all have recently 
conducted important national surveys such as the household income and expenditure survey. 
This allows the TA to use the most up-to-date empirical information in undertaking tasks on 
gender indicators, gender analyses, and country gender assessments.    
 
10.  Output  1:  Baseline  key  gender  indicators  are  compiled  and  maintained  by 
women’s  offices.  The  TA  will  help  women’s  ministries  and  sector  gender  focal  points  
(i) compile baseline gender indicators from existing administrative and statistical data sources; 
and (ii) establish a central, easy-to-use database that can be updated regularly as new data 
become available. In view of the lack of technical capacity among women’s ministry officials and 
gender focal points, the TA will provide in-country training on sex-disaggregated statistics, 
including a mapping of their data sources and their uses in assessing and monitoring gender 
inequality. It will also assist in establishing an interministerial network involving key government 
agencies such as the national statistics office (NSO), through which data need to be gathered 
and updated periodically. For countries that already have a working group on data gathering 
involving gender issues, such as Millennium Development Goal indicators or CEDAW status 
reports, the TA will assist in facilitating these working groups to compile gender indicators. A 
central database containing key gender indicators will be established either within the women’s 
ministry or in the NSO, and will be updated regularly. The compiled indicators will be posted on 
the NSO website. To harmonize with other data collection efforts by regional and international 
institutions, the list of key gender indicators will be established based on a regional gender 
indicator framework developed by the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC),6 and data 
compilation activities will be conducted in collaboration with the United Nations Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP).7   
 
11.  Output  2:  A  participatory,  evidence-based  country  gender  assessment  is 
completed in each participating DMC. A CGA will be undertaken in each participating country 
to obtain an in-depth understanding of gender disparities in each sector, to diagnose gender-
related barriers to inclusive social and economic development, and to recommend specific 
strategies to improve existing gender-related barriers. To achieve these goals, the CGAs will 
involve (i) conducting a gender analysis of national surveys for issues such as education, 
health,  economic  participation,  access to  assets  and  productive  resources,  and  household 
decision-making; (ii) incorporating findings from other gender research or specialized surveys 
such as gender-based violence; (iii) reviewing legal, policy, and institutional frameworks on 
gender equity; and (iv) assessing gender outcomes of major development or donor-assisted 
projects in key sectors. Along with these analytic components, the CGAs will be undertaken with 
participation  by  government  ministries,  women  stakeholders,  civil  society  groups,  and 
development partners. The TA will emphasize country ownership of the CGA so that its specific 
assessments  and  recommendations  can  be  incorporated  in the government’s  development 
strategies. Therefore, the structure of CGAs will vary from country to country to address the 
specific gender concerns of each country. The CGAs will be carried out in collaboration with

7  The TA will provide additional support for regional efforts on gender indicators which will be undertaken by SPC in

other development partners in each country, with each partner providing analytic inputs or 
general support to the assessment of sectors in their priority operations.   
 
12.  Output 3: Gender awareness is increased among government staff for gender-
inclusive  policy  development.  The  TA  will  help  women’s  offices  and  other  ministries 
disseminate the CGA findings widely across government ministries and civil society groups 
through national media events or meetings. Dissemination efforts will be aimed at (i) increasing 
gender awareness among policy makers as well as in civil society; (ii) addressing gaps in 
government  development  strategies  to  improve  gender-related  barriers;  and  (iii)  identifying 
priority areas for developing policy measures or government programs to improve women’s 
situations. Based on priority areas identified, the TA will support women’s ministry officers or 
sector gender focal points to draft specific gender strategies, action plans, or sector programs. 
The TA will also organize gender awareness training sessions for government officials in sector 
ministries and for managers of development projects to increase their understanding of gender 
aspects  of  development  and  foster  gender  mainstreaming  in  development  strategies  and 
projects. The TA will provide capacity building support through existing mechanisms established 
by  other  development  partners  in  each  country.  By  cooperating  and  collaborating  with 
development partners already working on gender issues (e.g., the United Nations Development 
Fund for Women), the TA aims to consolidate and strengthen ongoing efforts for capacity 
building and gender-inclusive development.    
 
13.  Output  4:  Awareness  of  gender  disparities  in  the  region  is  enhanced  among 
Pacific DMCs. The TA will support the production of a regional publication on Pacific gender 
indicators based on those compiled by each participating country under this TA, along with 
those compiled by SPC in other Pacific countries. The regional product will help each Pacific 
country better understand its own gender situations in comparison with other Pacific countries. 
This  regional  product  will  be  shared  at  regional  events  to  enhance  the  understanding  of 
common challenges in improving gender situations and to address possible gender strategies 
throughout the Pacific.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,640,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $1,450,000 on a 
grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV  and  TASF-other 
sources).8 The governments of the four participating DMCs will provide in-kind contributions with 
remuneration of counterpart staff totaling $100,000. UNESCAP will contribute the balance of 
$90,000 equivalent with the provision of staff time and administrative support.  The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented from January 2011 to June 2013.  ADB will be the executing 
agency and will be responsible for overall management and monitoring of the TA activities.   
 
16.  The TA will require a total of 102 person-months of international and national consulting 
services.  This  includes  45  person-months  of  international  consulting  services,  31  person-
months of national consulting services, and 26 person-months of ADB headquarters-based 
national  TA  coordinator  contributions.  ADB  will  engage  the  international  and  national 
consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
                                                
8  The TA will be financed by the combination of TASF-IV ($880,000) and TASF-other sources ($570,000).

5 
from time to time). All consultants will be recruited individually and selected on the basis of their 
qualifications  for  the  assignment.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in  
Appendix 3. All procurement of goods or equipment will be done in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).   
 
17.  UNESCAP will be the implementing agency for activities related to gender indicators. It 
will provide a statistician to assist the participating DMCs with (i) establishment of key gender 
indicators; (ii) compilation of gender statistics from administrative and statistical data sources; 
and (iii) in-country training to government staff on gender statistics. No objection letter from the 
participating  DMCs  will  be  obtained  before  TA  activities  begin  in  each  country.  TA 
implementation agreement outlining the roles and responsibilities will be signed between ADB 
and UNESCAP before the TA is implemented. An advance payment facility will be established 
to provide for UNESCAP travel expenses in connection with TA implementation in participating 
DMCs.9 Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  All  gender 
indicators compiled under the TA will be harmonized based on the SPC regional framework, 
and  be  provided  to the  SPC  regional  database  and  to  UNESCAP.  SPC  will  serve  as  an 
additional implementing agency in supporting regional activities related to gender indicators, 
including  the  compilation  of  gender  indicators  in  additional  Pacific  countries  such  as  the 
Marshall Islands and Tonga, and the regional publication and dissemination of gender indicators.       
 
18.  Progress will be monitored using the intended outcomes and outputs described in the 
design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1. The consultants will provide quarterly progress 
reports  and  completion  reports,  detailing  the  work  programs  and  achievements  of  their 
respective TA activities.  ADB will conduct periodic review missions to monitor TA activities. The 
TA results will be disseminated to participating DMCs as knowledge products and through 
regional events.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,450,000 on a grant basis 
for Promoting Evidence-Based Policy Making for Gender Equity in the Pacific, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of international and national consultants will be hired to assist the executing 
agency, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), in implementing the technical assistance (TA). All 
consultants will be recruited and hired individually according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The specific terms of reference for each 
consultant may vary from country to country, depending on the particular needs and priorities of 
each participating country and depending on collaborative frameworks agreed with development 
partners in each country.   
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Lead  Analyst  for  Country  Gender  Assessments  (17  person-months, 
intermittent) 
2.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  7  years  experience  working  on  gender  and 
development issues, including knowledge and experience of the Pacific context; experience in 
conducting  country  gender  assessments  (CGAs);  expertise  in  qualitative  and  quantitative 
research skills, including technical knowledge of gender analyses of national surveys; good 
consultation  and  leadership  skills  to  lead  the  discussion  with  governments,  collaborating 
partners, and civil society groups; and excellent writing and communication skills. 
 
3.  Under the supervision of the ADB TA project team leader, the consultant will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  develop frameworks for CGAs and for gender analyses of household surveys for 
each participating country, in discussion with the ADB project team leader; 
(ii)  prepare a detailed work plan and implementation schedules for CGAs, in close 
consultation with governments and development partners in each country;  
(iii)  prepare specific assignments for gender analysts and local consultants in each 
participating country; 
(iv)  conduct gender assessments for each sector, including assessments of legal and 
policy frameworks and reviews of development projects by governments and 
other development partners;    
(v)  coordinate all analytic inputs of the TA, including gender indicators and gender 
analyses of household surveys to produce CGAs; 
(vi)  coordinate and incorporate all the required inputs from development partners to 
produce a coherent document for the CGA in each country; 
(vii)  prepare  national  consultation  workshops  for  CGAs  including  a  final  CGA 
dissemination workshop, and lead the discussion at workshops in coordination 
with the government, development partners, and other stakeholders; 
(viii)  prepare the final draft of the CGA in each country for publication;  
(ix)  develop a regional knowledge product based on CGAs and other works; and 
(x)  submit quarterly reports on the progress of TA activities related to the CGAs.   
      
2.  Gender and Health Specialist for Country Gender Assessment in Papua 
New Guinea (3 person-months, intermittent) 
4.  The  consultant  will  have  expertise  in  gender  and  health  issues;  at  least  7  years  
experience  working  in  the  field;  excellent  analytic  skills  and  familiarity  with  health-sector 
development issues and HIV/AIDS in Papua New Guinea (PNG), including policy frameworks,

Appendix 3  11 
national development strategies, and donor activities; and good consultation and leadership 
skills to lead the CGA discussion with the government, collaborating partners, and civil society 
groups.   
  
5.  Working under the supervision of the ADB TA project team and lead analyst for CGA in 
PNG, the consultant’s specific tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  prepare detailed work plans for gender assessments for health and HIV/AIDS in 
PNG,  in  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of  Health,  National  AIDS  Council 
Secretariat, and development partners; 
(ii)  review  gender  issues  in  health  and  HIV/AIDS-related  indicators  based  on 
empirical  data  and  research,  as  well  as  existing  evidence  from  community 
consultations; 
(iii)  review policy frameworks, development strategies, and government and donor 
activities, and assess their relevance and impacts on health outcomes of women 
and men in PNG; 
(iv)  lead  discussion  with  the  government  and  development  partners  on  the 
challenges  and  opportunities  for  improving  the  health  and  HIV/AIDS  status 
especially for women, and prepare recommended strategies for the CGA; and 
(v)  prepare a report on CGA for health and HIV/AIDS, circulate for review, and 
incorporate comments from reviewers for the final report. 
 
3.  Gender Analyst for Household Surveys (15 person-months, intermittent) 
6.  The  consultant  will  have  a  graduate  degree  in  statistics,  demography,  economics, 
sociology, or a related area; at least 7 years experience in analyzing large national surveys on 
social and gender issues, such as poverty, education, health, employment, social protection, 
and  household  income;  and  experience  of  working  with  household  surveys,  such  as  the 
household income and expenditure survey or the demographic and health survey. 
 
7.  Working under the supervision of the ADB project team leader, the consultant will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  develop a detailed work plan for gender analyses of a specific household survey 
in each participating country, under the guidance of the ADB project team leader 
and lead analyst for CGAs;  
(ii)  conduct descriptive statistical analyses of the survey data on key gender issues 
according to work plans; 
(iii)  provide  data  analyses  for  TA  activities  on  gender  indicators  as  needed,  in 
discussion with UNESCAP statisticians; 
(iv)  ensure analyses are harmonized and consistent with the framework of gender 
indicators and with any report previously produced using the same survey;  
(v)  provide technical assistance on gender analysis of household surveys to national 
statistics offices (NSOs) as needed;  
(vi)  prepare all data programming files on gender indicators and gender analyses for 
submission to NSOs for follow-up analyses of future household surveys;  
(vii)  prepare a gender analysis report for each participating country, with a clear 
interpretation and assessment of statistical findings on each of the gender issues 
examined; and 
(viii)  prepare and submit quarterly progress reports.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
4.  Gender  Policy  and  Capacity  Building  Specialist  (10  person-months, 
intermittent) 
8.  The consultant will have at least 7 years experience working in gender-related policy or 
project development in developing countries, preferably with governments in Pacific countries. 
Working under the supervision of the ADB TA project team, the consultant will provide support 
to women’s ministry officers and sector gender focal points, by coordinating and strengthening 
activities  of  development  partners  in  each  participating  country.  Specific  tasks  include  the 
following: 
 
(i)  prepare plans to assist women’s ministries and sector gender focal points in 
disseminating and discussing the findings of CGAs and gender indicators, in 
consultation with the lead analyst for CGAs; 
(ii)  assist women’s ministries and gender focal points in leading the discussion at 
dissemination  and  consultation  meetings  involving  government  officials, 
nongovernment organizations, civil society groups, and other stakeholders; 
(iii)  identify the existing channel of information and collaboration between women’s 
ministries and sector gender focal points, and provide support for strengthening 
the working relationship between them; 
(iv)  conduct  gender  awareness  training  for  government  officials  and  project 
managers,  and  provide  refresher  training  to  national  consultants  and 
coordinators on gender awareness training for policy makers; 
(v)  identify  the  existing  policy  making  processes  and  provide  capacity  building 
support  to  women’s  ministry  officers,  sector  gender  focal  points,  and  other 
women’s  groups  in  preparing  and  drafting  gender  strategies  or  action  plans 
based on findings of gender indicators and CGAs;   
(vi)  ensure all capacity building activities take place in coordination with activities of 
government agencies and other development partners; and 
(vii)  prepare and submit quarterly progress reports. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  National Coordinators (28 person-months for all countries, intermittent)  
9.  The national consultant from each participating country will have at least a university 
degree with good analytic knowledge and skills on gender and development issues; at least  
3 years experience working on gender-related development projects; and excellent English 
writing, oral, and communication skills to help the international consultants and coordinate all TA 
activities. 
 
10.  Working under the supervision of the ADB project team leader, lead analyst for CGAs, 
and gender policy and capacity building specialist, the consultants’ tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  assist the lead analyst for CGAs by providing required inputs to CGAs, such as 
the  compilation  and  summary  analyses  of  gender  research  and  gender 
assessments of ADB projects; 
(ii)  assist the gender policy and capacity building specialist with dissemination and 
consultation workshops, and all activities related to capacity building support; 
(iii)  attend  all  gender  meetings  organized  by  the  government  and  development 
partners as a coordinator for ADB, along with international consultants;

Appendix 3  13 
(iv)  assist the international consultants and other TA team members in arranging 
meetings and activities with government officials and development partners; 
(v)  organize and coordinate national meetings and in-country consultations including 
logistic arrangements and administrative preparations; 
(vi)  prepare materials for national meetings and assist the international consultants 
with publication materials on gender indicators and CGAs;  
(vii)  assist  and  coordinate  all  other  TA  activities  in  the  country,  including 
administrative, technical, and logistic support; and 
(viii)  prepare inputs to quarterly progress reports of TA activities.    
 
2.  Information Technology Support Specialist (3 person-months for all countries, 
intermittent) 
11.  The consultant will have skills in data management softwares and at least 3 years 
experience in providing training on the use and maintenance of data management softwares. 
Working under the guidance of the UNESCAP statistician and information technology specialist, 
as well as the ADB TA project team, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  provide assistance to women’s offices or NSOs in setting up a database software 
for the compilation of gender indicators; 
(ii)  provide training on the use and maintenance of the database for regular updating 
of gender indicators; and  
(iii)  provide additional information technology training and ongoing support for data 
management of gender indicators as needed by women’s ministries or NSOs. 
 
3.  TA Project Coordinator (26 person-months, intermittent) 
12.  The TA project coordinator, to be based at ADB headquarters, will assist the ADB 
project team leader and other consultants to plan, organize, implement, monitor, and evaluate 
TA activities. The coordinator must have working knowledge and experience with ADB business 
procedures  on  project  implementation,  financial  recording,  and  other  project-related 
administrative matters.     
 
13.  Under  the  supervision  of  the  ADB  project  team  leader,  the  coordinator  will  be 
responsible for the following TA-related activities: 
 
(i)  coordinate  all  TA  activities  with  international  and  national  consultants  in 
participating countries and monitor the progress of TA activities; 
(ii)  liaise with concerned offices, partners, institutions, and governments in securing 
appropriate decisions and actions to support TA activities; 
(iii)  prepare and make logistic arrangements for national workshops, in coordination 
with national consultants, ADB resident offices, and other development partners; 
(iv)  manage and maintain all project records, including financial reports of the TA; 
(v)  prepare quarterly progress reports, by consolidating reports from all consultants; 
(vi)  prepare project briefs, presentation materials, and publications; and 
(vii)  assist the ADB project team leader with recruitment of consultants and contract 
variations, if necessary.
